Deciding when to stop driving is one of the hardest parts of dementia care. This isn‚Äôt just about protecting the person with dementia ‚Äî it‚Äôs about protecting everyone on the road. There‚Äôs no one-size-fits-all solution, but there are creative ways to preserve dignity while keeping everyone safe. Sometimes it takes trial and error to find what works.

If you‚Äôve navigated this with your loved one, share in the comments what strategies worked ‚Äî or didn‚Äôt work ‚Äî for you. Your experience might help another caregiver! And if you have more questions, drop those below too.

Contessa‚Äôs Caregiver Tips: 
Building strong relationships with clients and their families is essential in caregiving, but it‚Äôs important to keep personal information private. Maintaining professionalism ensures boundaries are respected and prevents personal matters from affecting your job performance. Protect your privacy while providing exceptional care!

items.text: Japan is experiencing a surge in elderly female prisoners, with the number of prisoners aged 65 or older nearly quadrupling from 2003 to 2022. This rise comes as elderly women seek companionship and structure in prison for a chance at a better end to their lives, as they increasingly face loneliness in the outside world. CNN's Hanako Montgomery visited Tochigi, Japan‚Äôs largest women‚Äôs prison, to meet these elderly inmates and the guards who care for them. To read the full report head to CNN.com

What Does Caregiver Burnout Look Like? üåü

Caregiving is a labor of love, but it can take a toll. Here are some signs of caregiver burnout to watch for:

üí§ Exhaustion ‚Äì Feeling physically and emotionally drained, even after rest.
üåßÔ∏è Increased Anxiety or Depression ‚Äì Struggling with feelings of hopelessness or worry.
üò§ Irritability ‚Äì Losing patience easily with your loved one or others.
üò¥ Sleep Problems ‚Äì Insomnia or sleeping too much.
üí≠ Forgetfulness ‚Äì Difficulty concentrating or remembering tasks.
üçî Changes in Appetite ‚Äì Eating too much or too little.
üìâ Health Issues ‚Äì Frequent headaches, stomach issues, or getting sick more often.
üö™ Withdrawal ‚Äì Avoiding friends, family, or activities you once enjoyed.

Taking care of yourself is just as important as caring for your loved one. You don't have to do this alone.

üìû Call Bridge to Home today to learn how we can support you and your loved one. Let us help lighten the load and bring balance back to your life.

üíô You care for them; we care for you. üíô

Hydration tips for an aging parent‚ù§Ô∏èüí¶

My partner and I are caregiver for her elderly mom who has dementia. She is not a big fan of drinking throughout the day, because she does not like the inconvenience of using the restroom. 

But obviously, hydration is super important. So we figured out a couple of ways to keep her hydrated without annoying her too much. 

If you‚Äôre caring for an aging parent or grandparent at home who is also not a fan of drinking throughout the day, maybe give these tricks a try

items.text:
Caring for someone with dementia? These 10 simple rules can change everything. Save this for the hard days.
Agree, never argue.
Redirect, never reason.
Distract, never shame.
Reassure, never lecture.
Reminisce, never say ‚Äúremember.‚Äù
Repeat, never say ‚ÄúI told you.‚Äù
Do what they can do, never say ‚Äúyou can‚Äôt.‚Äù
Ask, never demand.
Encourage, never condescend.
Reinforce, never force.
#homecare #dementia #boston #caregiving

items.text: What bipolar caregiver burnout actually looks like‚Äîduring manic episodes or crisis situations.‚Äù When you‚Äôre supporting someone through a bipolar episode, your body breaks down, even if your heart doesn‚Äôt. You keep their hours, carry their pain, and second-guess your reactions. This isn‚Äôt about blame‚Äîit‚Äôs about understanding. Both the person with bipolar and the person loving them through it deserve space to heal. You can love someone and still feel exhausted. You can be in crisis and still be worthy of love. Both things are true. This isn‚Äôt clinical advice‚Äîit‚Äôs caregiver insight, but sometimes it‚Äôs based on clinical research I‚Äôve done. Everyone‚Äôs different‚Äîthis is just what helped our family. Talk to a licensed professional before trying anything new. Lived experience + clinically backed info. Not a doctor or therapist‚Äîalways consult a professional. #BipolarCaregiver #BipolarMania #CaregiverBurnout #MentalHealthSupport #bipolareducation
